overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students learn that a compound event combines two or more events using the word and or or. They identify the outcomes that make up an <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> or <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math> event and calculate the probability. Students rewrite a probability question with an <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math> statement as the sum of each eventâ€™s probability without counting an outcome twice when it pertains to both events. They apply their understanding in a game context.

overview_item_data_items: I can calculate probabilities of compound events using tables.
I can represent the sample space for compound events and calculate probabilities of compound events using tree diagrams.
A compound event combines two or more events, using the word <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> or the word <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math>.

An <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> statement means that both outcomes must occur. An <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math> statement means that that one, the other, or both outcomes must occur.
The probability of a compound event with the word <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> is the probability of two or more simultaneous events.
The probability of a compound event with the word <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math> is the probability of one or more simple events occurring.
When solving a probability question with <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math>, be sure to list outcomes that apply to both events only one time.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students sort items into a Venn diagram to compare and categorize them based on their characteristics.
Students analyze strategies for calculating probability with an <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> or statement.
Students identify the successes that make up an <math><mi>a</mi><mi>n</mi><mi>d</mi></math> or <math><mi>o</mi><mi>r</mi></math> event and calculate the probability.
Students analyze the rules of a game to determine who is more likely to win.

overview_item_data_items: If facilitating this lesson without student devices, no additional materials are needed.
To avoid printing additional materials not included in MATHbook (like Activate activities and Session Quick Checks) project them using the Present button above.
